First, we need to understand what the 23rd amendment is. The 23rd amendment was added to the US Constitution in 1961, granting residents of Washington D.C. the right to vote for president and vice president. This amendment did not mention Puerto Rico or any other US territories.

Therefore, the answer to the question is no, the 23rd amendment did not give Puerto Ricans the right to vote for president. Puerto Rico is a US territory, and residents of US territories do not have the same right to vote for president as residents of the 50 states and D.C. do.

Puerto Ricans can vote in Presidential primaries, but they are not allowed to vote for president in the general election. Only US citizens who reside in the 50 states or D.C. are allowed to vote in the general election for president.
